DOC.HEAD: Company Sues Union for $60 Million, Alleges Racketeering

Eds: CORRECTS style on `lawsuit' throughout; SUBS 4th graf, `The suit ... to CORRECT name of the racketeering statute to Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act, CORRECT style on usage; SUBS 9th graf, `Calls to ..., with 2 grafs to UPDATE with union comment; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A strike-bound coal company sued the United Mine Workers for $60 million Wednesday, accusing the union and its members of attempted murder, arson and extortion as part of a nationwide racketeering scheme. The lawsuit was filed in federal court in Beckley by the New Beckley Mining Corp., which also announced it will close its nearby Glen Daniel mine because of what it called union violence stemming from the UMW's selective strikes. The UMW has been on strike against New Beckley since January, idling 130 miners. The union also is engaged in a bitter strike against the Pittston Coal Group Inc. in West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky. The lawsuit was filed under the Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act. Although the racketeering statute was intended by Congress primarily as a tool against organized crime, it been used frequently against unions, including a 1988 lawsuit by the government against the the Teamsters. Earlier this year, the Supreme Court upheld the use of the statute against legitimate organizations, despite complaints by the AFL-CIO that it had become ``a tool of harassment ... against legitimate businesses and labor organizations.'' The New Beckley Mining lawsuit cites alleged violence at more than 20 coal companies in West Virginia, Kentucky and Virginia since 1983, when the union began its selective strike strategy, in which the UMW targeted specific companies for work stoppages. Previous strikes were industrywide. The lawsuit alleges that New Beckley employees have been the targets of vandalism, death threats, shootings and beatings at work and at home. The violence ``pervades the coal industry, discouraging productivity and inhibiting the economic well-being of individuals living and working in coal-producing communities,'' the lawsuit says. Union spokesman John Duray called the lawsuit ``ridiculous'' and accused the company of engaging in a ``press-release lawsuit'' by hiring a public relations company to notify the news media of the filing. ``It looks to me like these guys are a lot more interested in trying their case in the media than in court,'' Duray said. District 29 President Everett Acord said he knew nothing of the lawsuit or the mine closing. At a news conference on the courthouse steps, New Beckley President Jay Sasell said: ``The decision to shut down and seal New Beckley's Glen Daniel Mine was reached because the continued organized violence orchestrated against New Beckley by the UMWA has reached an intolerable level of acceptability by any rational standard. ``Marauding pickets continue to cause great hardship upon the company and its families on a daily basis.'' The lawsuit contends that the union has engaged in a pattern of racketeering that includes 34 counts of attempted murder, 23 of arson and 79 of extortion. Under the RICO statute, the company's requested $20 million in damages can be tripled if the union and various individuals are found to have violated the act.
